headline: Tech Weekly: precious chip deals, precious metals
summary: STORY: From precious chip deals to precious metals.This is Tech Weekly.:: Tech WeeklyNvidia CEO Jensen Huang said the company has seen "very strong demand" for its advanced Blackwell chips.And it's producing the semiconductors with the help of TSMC's wafers.Huang even said Nvidia's success wouldn't be possible without the Taiwanese firm's support on wafers.Nvidia made history last month when it became the first company to reach a $5 trillion market value.Apple won't release the next version of the iPhone Air in the fall of 2026 as previously planned.That's according to sources familiar with the matter.The company launched the iPhone Air in 2025 as a thinner and lighter alternative within its iPhone portfolio.The model came with some trade-offs in terms of battery size and camera features.CEO Elon Musk said Tesla will likely have to build a chip fab to make AI semiconductors.And he said the EV maker could work with U.S. firm Intel.Tesla is designing its fifth-generation AI chip to power its autonomous ambitions.Musk raised the issue at the company's annual meeting."As far as I can see, the only option is to go build some very big chip fab."The AA Driving School Academy says trainee driving instructors are turning to virtual reality to master complex road scenarios in a safe, controlled environment.Using Meta’s Quest 3 headsets, the driving school can introduce instructors to modern hazards.Including a higher number of cyclists and scooters.UK startup DEScycle is dissolving discarded tech using "deep eutectic solvent" chemistry to pull out precious and critical metals at room temperature.It's an alternative to energy-hungry smelting.And DEScycle says the liquids selectively dissolve metals from shredded circuit boards and other e‑waste while leaving most non‑metal components behind.

raw.headline: Tech Weekly: precious chip deals, precious metals
raw.summary: STORY: From precious chip deals to precious metals.This is Tech Weekly.:: Tech WeeklyNvidia CEO Jensen Huang said the company has seen "very strong demand" for its advanced Blackwell chips.And it's producing the semiconductors with the help of TSMC's wafers.Huang even said Nvidia's success wouldn't be possible without the Taiwanese firm's support on wafers.Nvidia made history last month when it became the first company to reach a $5 trillion market value.Apple won't release the next version of the iPhone Air in the fall of 2026 as previously planned.That's according to sources familiar with the matter.The company launched the iPhone Air in 2025 as a thinner and lighter alternative within its iPhone portfolio.The model came with some trade-offs in terms of battery size and camera features.CEO Elon Musk said Tesla will likely have to build a chip fab to make AI semiconductors.And he said the EV maker could work with U.S. firm Intel.Tesla is designing its fifth-generation AI chip to power its autonomous ambitions.Musk raised the issue at the company's annual meeting."As far as I can see, the only option is to go build some very big chip fab."The AA Driving School Academy says trainee driving instructors are turning to virtual reality to master complex road scenarios in a safe, controlled environment.Using Meta’s Quest 3 headsets, the driving school can introduce instructors to modern hazards.Including a higher number of cyclists and scooters.UK startup DEScycle is dissolving discarded tech using "deep eutectic solvent" chemistry to pull out precious and critical metals at room temperature.It's an alternative to energy-hungry smelting.And DEScycle says the liquids selectively dissolve metals from shredded circuit boards and other e‑waste while leaving most non‑metal components behind.

headline: Cloud AI Update - Cloud Computing Market Set For Significant 2033 Growth
summary: The U.S. cloud computing market is expected to experience significant growth, expanding from $221.69 billion in 2024 to $871.61 billion by 2033, driven by a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 16.43%. This expansion is fueled by digital transformations across various industries such as manufacturing, finance, and healthcare, alongside growing demands for SaaS and secure cloud solutions. While challenges like data security and compliance persist, these are being addressed through government...

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSM) Posts Slowest Monthly Growth Since Early Last Year
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (NYSE:TSM) is among the most profitable semiconductor stocks to buy. As reported on November 10, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (NYSE:TSM) delivered a revenue growth of 16.9% YoY in October, which is lower than the 39.6% increase in September and the slowest pace since February last year.
